I ran pip install word cloud and this is happening in my macOS when I try to create a word cloud. 

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

a short, self-contained correct example to reproduce (see http://sscce.org/).

items.body:

No module named 'wordcloud.query_integral_image'

The version of wordcloud installed is 1.7.0

items.title: Stopwords that end in -s are counted as plurals (i.e. "was" being counted as "wa")
items.body:
#### Description
Stopwords that end in -s are counted as plurals (i.e. "was" being counted as "wa", and displayed on any resulting wordclouds, if "wa" is present in the input text).

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
In `a_file.txt`, there is one instance of the word ` wa `, and 225 instances of the word ` was ` (among lots of other text).

```python
from wordcloud import WordCloud
f = open('a_file.txt', 'r').read()
wordcloud = WordCloud().generate(f)
d = (WordCloud().process_text(f))
print(d['wa'])
wordcloud.to_file('out.png')
```
This prints 226, and in the resulting wordcloud the `wa` is very large. 

### (Suspected) Cause

This snippet in `tokenization.py` would combine the dictionary entries for `was` and `wa`:

```python
for key in list(d.keys()):
            if key.endswith('s') and not key.endswith("ss"):
                key_singular = key[:-1]
                if key_singular in d:
                    dict_plural = d[key]
                    dict_singular = d[key_singular]
                    for word, count in dict_plural.items():
                        singular = word[:-1]
                        dict_singular[singular] = (
                            dict_singular.get(singular, 0) + count)
                    merged_plurals[key] = key_singular
                    del d[key]
```


#### Versions
Darwin-18.5.0-x86_64-i386-64bit
Python 3.7.4 (default, Oct 12 2019, 18:55:28) 
[Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.8)]
NumPy 1.18.1
matplotlib 3.2.1
wordcoud 1.7.0

items.title: Using wordcloud source without installing the module
items.body:
Because of #540 I clone the repo and want to run a development version from the source. 
I get the error:

`
import wordcloud
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ModuleNotFoundError                       Traceback (most recent call last)
c:\Users\basti\Documents\GitHub\word_cloud\development.py in 
----> 2 import wordcloud

c:\Users\basti\Documents\GitHub\word_cloud\wordcloud\__init__.py in 
----> 1 from .wordcloud import (WordCloud, STOPWORDS, random_color_func,
      2                         get_single_color_func)
      3 from .color_from_image import ImageColorGenerator
      4 
      5 __all__ = ['WordCloud', 'STOPWORDS', 'random_color_func',

c:\Users\basti\Documents\GitHub\word_cloud\wordcloud\wordcloud.py in 
     28 from PIL import ImageFont
     29 
---> 30 from .query_integral_image import query_integral_image
     31 from .tokenization import unigrams_and_bigrams, process_tokens
     32 

ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'wordcloud.query_integral_image'`

which makes sense as there is only a .c file and in the setup.py extensions this is mentioned, so I gues this gets translated by setuptools to something usable for the python interpreter.

So I guess my question is: Is there a way to use the source without executing setup.py?

items.title: How to make colors consistent?
items.body:
Hi, I am a newbie. I'm in trouble. This is the case. If I set the color of all words to red, the end result is that not all words are red. Some words are shifted in color, and some are darker in color.
If I want the same color, how should i do? I use Google Translate. Am I clear?

```
from wordcloud import (WordCloud, get_single_color_func)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


class GroupedColorFunc(object):
    """Create a color function object which assigns DIFFERENT SHADES of
       specified colors to certain words based on the color to words mapping.
       Uses wordcloud.get_single_color_func
       Parameters
       ----------
       color_to_words : dict(str -> list(str))
         A dictionary that maps a color to the list of words.
       default_color : str
         Color that will be assigned to a word that's not a member
         of any value from color_to_words.
    """

    def __init__(self, color_to_words, default_color):
        self.color_func_to_words = [
            (get_single_color_func(color), set(words))
            for (color, words) in color_to_words.items()]

        self.default_color_func = get_single_color_func(default_color)

    def get_color_func(self, word):
        """Returns a single_color_func associated with the word"""
        try:
            color_func = next(
                color_func for (color_func, words) in self.color_func_to_words
                if word in words)
        except StopIteration:
            color_func = self.default_color_func

        return color_func

    def __call__(self, word, **kwargs):
        return self.get_color_func(word)(word, **kwargs)


text = """The Zen of Python, by Tim Peters
Beautiful is better than ugly.
Explicit is better than implicit.
Simple is better than complex.
Complex is better than complicated.
Flat is better than nested.
Sparse is better than dense.
Readability counts.
Special cases aren't special enough to break the rules.
Although practicality beats purity.
Errors should never pass silently.
Unless explicitly silenced.
In the face of ambiguity, refuse the temptation to guess.
There should be one-- and preferably only one --obvious way to do it.
Although that way may not be obvious at first unless you're Dutch.
Now is better than never.
Although never is often better than *right* now.
If the implementation is hard to explain, it's a bad idea.
If the implementation is easy to explain, it may be a good idea.
Namespaces are one honking great idea -- let's do more of those!"""

# Since the text is small collocations are turned off and text is lower-cased
wc = WordCloud(collocations=False, background_color='white').generate(text.lower())

color_to_words = {
    # words below will be colored with a green single color function
    'red': ['beautiful', 'explicit', 'simple', 'sparse',
                'readability', 'rules', 'practicality',
                'explicitly', 'one', 'now', 'easy', 'obvious', 'better'],
    # will be colored with a red single color function
    'red': ['ugly', 'implicit', 'complex', 'complicated', 'nested',
            'dense', 'special', 'errors', 'silently', 'ambiguity',
            'guess', 'hard']
}

# Words that are not in any of the color_to_words values
# will be colored with a grey single color function
default_color = 'red'

# Create a color function with single tone
# grouped_color_func = SimpleGroupedColorFunc(color_to_words, default_color)

# Create a color function with multiple tones
grouped_color_func = GroupedColorFunc(color_to_words, default_color)

# Apply our color function
wc.recolor(color_func=grouped_color_func)

# Plot
plt.figure()
plt.imshow(wc, interpolation="bilinear")
plt.axis("off")
plt.show()
```

```python
import pandas as pd

from collections import Counter
```

items.title: Remove stopwords after creating bigrams to prevent incorrect bigrams
items.body:
#### Description
I am dealing with a corpus that contains the phrase "thank you very much" frequently.  Currently this phrase results in a bigram "thank much".  The cause appears to be generating the bigrams after removing the stopwords.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
Create a word cloud containing frequent phrases having internal stopwords.

#### Expected Results
I expected one of two things.  Either that 1) "thank you", "very much" would be frequent bigrams (but not "you very", which consists entirely of stopwords.)  Or that 2) "thank" and "much" would show up as frequent unigrams.  I think the first option is the more elegant solution.

#### Actual Results
"thank much" was a frequent bigram.

#### Versions
```
>>> import wordcloud; print("wordcoud", wordcloud.__version__)
wordcoud 1.6.0
```

items.body:
Hi there,

Thanks for the wonderful pacakge. I was wondering if there is any preferred method to cite/acknowledge use of this package in an article/presentation?

items.title: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'wordcloud.query_integral_image'，help！！！
items.body:
#### Description
I am a completely new pythoner, I just want to plot some beautiful pictures for my report. I come accross some problem when studying "wordcloud".

I tried to install "wordcloud" under pycharm and it said I need to install visual c++ 14, I downloaded and installed but it still showed the same message. I then download the whl file from https://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/#wordcloud, change the "whl" to zip, then unzip, copy the file "wordcloud" and "wordcloud-1.5.0.dist-info" to python\Lib\site-packages. Then went to pycharm---file---settings---project interpreter add the "wordcloud", after a few moment,  it finally said installed successfully!!!

Then I tried to run the following code:

from wordcloud import WordCloud
f=open(r'D:\Data visualization\practice\mechtronics.txt', 'r').read()
wordcloud=WordCloud(background_color='white', width=1000, height=860, margin=2).generate(f)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.imshow(wordcloud)
plt.axis('off')
plt.show()
wordcloud.to_file('test.png')

T-T
I got the error said:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "D:/Data visualization/practice_wordcloud/mechatronics.py", line 1, in <module>
    from wordcloud import WordCloud
  File "D:\soft\python\lib\site-packages\wordcloud\__init__.py", line 1, in <module>
    from .wordcloud import (WordCloud, STOPWORDS, random_color_func,
  File "D:\soft\python\lib\site-packages\wordcloud\wordcloud.py", line 25, in <module>
    from .query_integral_image import query_integral_image
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'wordcloud.query_integral_image'


I have no idea how to fix it, hope anyone who had similar problem can give me some clue! Thanks!



<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->

```python
from wordcloud import WordCloud
```
```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

text = "Facebook has been the target of probes by various governments after news broke about a year ago that it allowed the personal data of tens of millions of users to be shared with political consultancy Cambridge Analytica. Millions of users also had personal information accessed via a recent breach."
```

items.title: wordcloud has a right single quotes in picture
items.body:
#### Description

![全唐诗+春风](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42257971/55218804-21cc5500-523e-11e9-86d2-937b2654308f.jpg)
![全唐诗+春风+1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42257971/55218986-930c0800-523e-11e9-90d6-ff167d3e4b7b.jpg)

When generating a Chinese word cloud, the image has a right single quotation mark.
I can't use lcut because it always fails to correctly participle Chinese tang poetry.
I also can't use '.join(hanlp. Segment ()) because the word cloud is different when i spliced the string.
If I want a word cloud chart that has the same effect as pyecharts wordcloud, I must use str(list), but at this point each word is followed by a close single quotation mark.
Would you like to help me remove the single quotation mark?thank you very much.
rawen 
rawen0623@live.com

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
def getTxtbyword(fn,word):
    fo=open(fn,'r',encoding='utf-8')
    txt=fo.readlines()#注意按行读取，以方便去除带有符号的标题。
    fo.close()
    ls=''
    for i in txt:
        if '【' in i:
            i='!'+i[i.find('】')+1:].replace(' ','').strip('\n')+i[i.find('【'):i.find('】')+1].strip('\n')#在标题前加上！符号，以用于后续的分隔
            ls+=i
        else:
            ls+=i.strip('\n')
    ms=ls.split('!')
    fl=[]
    for i in ms:#搜索带有指定字的行，并加入列表fl,列表的结构为作者+标题+文章
        if word in i:
            fl.append(i)
    qs = ''
    for i in fl:
        i = i.split('】', 2)[1].replace('，', '').replace('。', '')  #用将此首诗分为两部分并取后部分，前部分是作者+标题，后部分是诗的内容
        qs += i
    return qs

def getWordconnection(fn,word):
    qs=getTxtbyword(fn,word)#qs is a string
    HanLP.Config.ShowTermNature=False
    c=HanLP.segment(qs)
    ls=[]
    for i in c:
        ls.append(i.word)#i.word是单词,i.nature是词性（只有当hanlp.config.showtermnature为false时才有词性。
    mask=imread('tangmap.png')#用wordcloud中的词云
    w=WordCloud(width=1366,height=768,font_path='simkai.ttf',mask=mask,background_color='pink',max_words=400)
    w.generate(str(ls))
    w.to_file('{}+{}.jpg'.format(fn[0:-4],word))

#### Versions
<!--
Please run the following snippet and paste the output below.
import platform; print(platform.platform())
import sys; print("Python", sys.version)
import numpy; print("NumPy", numpy.__version__)
import matplotlib; print("matplotlib", matplotlib.__version__)
import wordcloud; print("wordcoud", wordcloud.__version__)

Here is an image: #### Steps/Code to Reproduce I use Jupyter notebook, this is the code: ``` from wordcloud import WordCloud import matplotlib.pyplot as plt %matplotlib inline data = dict([ ('A',20),('B',100),('C',888),('D',14),('E',132) ]) wordcloud = WordCloud(max_font_size=100) wordcloud.generate_from_frequencies(data) plt.figure() plt.imshow(wordcloud) plt.axis("off") plt.show() ``` #### Expected Results The words should be duplicated by their frequencies #### Actual Results Each word appears only once, disregarding the frequency #### Versions ``` Darwin-17.7.0-x86_64-i386-64bit Python 3.7.1 (default, Dec 14 2018, 13:28:58) [Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)] NumPy 1.15.4 matplotlib 3.0.2 wordcoud 1.5.0 ```

items.title: Regexp from cli
items.body:
I passed the standard regex you used in the code `r"\w[\w']+"` at CLI as follows:

```bash
wordcloud_cli --no_collocations --regexp r"\w[\w']+" --stopwords="${TempStopWordP}" --text "${SourceP}" --width 800 --height 100 --imagefile "${TagP}"
```

But the forst letter of each word disappears from the wordcloud. What should I change here? I tried different quoting like `"r\"\w[\w\']+\""`, but this is not matching any word.

Also, could you please explain the regex. I know that `\w` means `[a-zA-Z0-9]` and `+` is 1 or more. what is `\w'` and `r`?

items.title: Hebrew word cloud
items.body:
I'm not able to produce word cloud from a Hebrew text. 
The code builds on a standard example for producing English clouds

`from wordcloud import WordCloud, STOPWORDS 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
text = open('health_example-liver.txt', 'r').read()
`

The text seems to be decoded well:
`print (text)`

Gives:

> 'דלקת כבד נגיפית היא דלקת של הכבד , הנגרמת על ידי נגיפים וגורמים שונים .\nהדלקת פוגעת בכבד , הורסת אותו ועלולה להוביל לאשפוז ואף לגרום למוות .\nקיימים לפחות שישה זנים שונים של נגיף דלקת הכבד , לרבות הזנים A , B ו - C .\nהזנים B ו - C נחשבים לזנים הקשים ביותר , הפוגעים במספר הרב ביותר של אנשים .\nדלקת כבד נגיפית C נחשבת למגפה שקטה , מכיוון שהתסמינים מתפתחים בפחות ממחצית מהאנשים הנגועים ופחות prefix=מ - 30 % מהחולים הנגועים בנגיף HCV , יודעים כי הם נושאים את הזיהום .\n80 % מהנפגעים במחלה הופכים להיות חולים כרוניים ואילו 5 % מחולי הפטיטיס C יפתחו סרטן הכבד .\nגורמי prefix=סיכון 1 .\nשימוש במזרקים מזוהמים : גורם הסיכון הנפוץ ביותר לזיהום בדלקת כבד נגיפית מסוג C הנו הזרקת סמים תוך ורידית .\nאנשים המזריקים סמים נמצאים בסיכון גבוה להידבק , זאת משום שצרכני סמים נוטים לחלוק ביניהם את המחטים העלולות להיות מזוהמות בדם הנגוע בנגיף HCV .\n60 % - 80 מכל המשתמשים בסמים תוך ורידיים נגועים בנגיף .\n2 .\nקעקועים ופירסינג : הזיהום עלול לעבור מאדם אחד למשנהו , אם מכון הקעקועים / פירסינג אינו מקפיד על ביצוע חיטוי נאות של הציוד .\nכאשר הציוד מזוהם , חלקיקי דם מיקרוסקופיים עלולים להישאר בצבע ובמחטים שנעשה בהם שימוש בכל סוג של פעולה .\nתסמיניםהתסמינים לדלקת כבד נגיפית C הם בדרך כלל שקטים ועשויים לכלול : • עייפות .\n• אובדן תאבון .\n• כאב בטן .\n• שתן כהה .\n• הצהבת העור או העיניים ( צהבת ) במקרים נדירים .\nרופא יכול לבצע שתי בדיקות דם ספציפיות לנגיף HCV : בדיקת ElISA ( ניסיון ספיגה חיסונית קשור - אנזים ) או בדיקת נוגדנים , ובדיקת PCR ( תגובת שרשרת של אנזים פולים ) .\nאנשים הנמצאים בסיכון ורוצים להיבדק , צריכים לשוחח עם הרופא המטפל שלהם ולבקש בדיקת דם ל - HCV .\nטיפול רפואיכיום , אין חיסון לדלקת כבד נגיפית C .\nהדרך הטובה ביותר להישמר מנגיף ה - HCV הינה הימנעות מפעילויות המסווגות כבעלות סיכון גבוה .\nאם נודע לך שנדבקת בנגיף , עליך לפעול בשיתוף עם הרופא וצוות הטיפול שלך באופן מיידי לפיתוח תוכנית טיפול המתאימה לך .\nהמידע באדיבות חברת שרינג פלאו .\nשבוע המודעות לפטיטיס C ייערך prefix=ב - 17 - 21 ביוני .\nבואו לדבר על זה בפורום כירורגיה של הכבד ודרכי המרה .\n'

But the cloud produced includes only the English words:
`# Create the wordcloud object
wordcloud = WordCloud(width=480, height=480, margin=0).generate(text)
 
# Display the generated image:
plt.imshow(wordcloud, interpolation='bilinear')
plt.axis("off")
plt.margins(x=0, y=0)
plt.show()`

The result is: 
![heb_word_cloud](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30949452/50545504-70a62680-0c1e-11e9-93be-dd714024f523.png)

I consulted with the previous foreign language support issues but did not find a solution. 
Your help will be appreciated

items.title: generate_from_frequencies() raise ZeroDivisionError when there're more than one zero in the data
items.body:
#### Description
Similar Issue: [Issue 308](https://github.com/amueller/word_cloud/issues/308)

At line 464 in wordcloud.py:
```
if rs != 0:
                font_size = int(round((rs * (freq / float(last_freq))
                                       + (1 - rs)) * font_size))
```

If last_freq == 0 (more than one zero in the data), ZeroDivisionError will be raised.

And I'm using generate_from_frequencies() for plotting not only frequency data, but other statistics, such as p-values, chi-square, etc. Decimals are fine, too many zeros would raise the error. I haven't tested negative values (in some cases negative values do make sense, for example in statistics), so I'm not sure whether using negative values as input data will cause any other problems. 

The workaround I'm using now is to manually remove all zeros in my data (and negative values too, I suppose), but there might be not enough words in the figure. Another workaround is to replace all zeros with a very small number, for example 0.0000000001, which produces better results.

Thanks in advance.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

Example:
```
import wordcloud

word_cloud = wordcloud.WordCloud()

word_cloud.generate_from_frequencies({'test': 1, 'test1': 0, 'test2': 2}) # OK
word_cloud.generate_from_frequencies({'test': 1, 'test1': 0, 'test2': 0}) # Error
```

#### Versions
Windows-10-10.0.17134-SP0
Python 3.7.1 (v3.7.1:260ec2c36a, Oct 20 2018, 14:57:15) [MSC v.1915 64 bit (AMD64)]
matplotlib 3.0.2
wordcoud 1.5.0

items.title: How do I unpack the `wordcloud.wordcloud.WordCloud` object, so that I can extract the positions and sizes of the words?
items.body:
After generating the wordcloud like so, `wordcloud.generate(text)`, how do I unpack the wordcloud object?

When I return the wordcloud object, it just returns `<wordcloud.wordcloud.WordCloud at 0x1c8eaba3860>`:

```
def plot_wordcloud(text, mask=None, max_words=200, max_font_size=100, figure_size=(24.0,16.0), 
                   title = None, title_size=40, image_color=False):
    stopwords = set(STOPWORDS)
    wordcloud = WordCloud(background_color='black',
                    stopwords = stopwords,
                    max_words = max_words,
                    max_font_size = max_font_size, 
                    random_state = 42,
                    width=800, 
                    height=400,
                    mask = mask)
    return wordcloud.generate(str(text))

word_list = "Wikipedia was launched on January 15, 2001, by Jimmy Wales and Larry Sanger.[10] Sanger coined its name,[11][12] as a portmanteau of wiki[notes 3] and 'encyclopedia'. Initially an English-language encyclopedia, versions in other languages were quickly developed. With 5,748,461 articles,[notes 4] the English Wikipedia is the largest of the more than 290 Wikipedia encyclopedias. Overall, Wikipedia comprises more than 40 million articles in 301 different languages[14] and by February 2014 it had reached 18 billion page views and nearly 500 million unique visitors per month.[15] In 2005, Nature published a peer review comparing 42 science articles from Encyclopædia Britannica and Wikipedia and found that Wikipedia's level of accuracy approached that of Britannica.[16] Time magazine stated that the open-door policy of allowing anyone to edit had made Wikipedia the biggest and possibly the best encyclopedia in the world and it was testament to the vision of Jimmy Wales.[17] Wikipedia has been criticized for exhibiting systemic bias, for presenting a mixture of 'truths, half truths, and some falsehoods',[18] and for being subject to manipulation and spin in controversial topics.[19] In 2017, Facebook announced that it would help readers detect fake news by suitable links to Wikipedia articles. YouTube announced a similar plan in 2018."

plot_wordcloud(word_list, title="Word Cloud")

>>> <wordcloud.wordcloud.WordCloud at 0x1c8eaba3860>
```

items.title: ImportError: No module named 'matplotlib'
items.body:
#### Description

Attempting to troubleshoot #446, I tried installing wordcloud and constructing a WordCloud, but got an ImportError on matplotlib.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

`rwt wordcloud -- -c '__import__("wordcloud").WordCloud()'`

#### Expected Results

Process should run with an exit code of 0. Reading the other tickets, wordcloud is supposed to be usable without matplotlib, but it seems that simply constructing a WordCloud object requires matplotlib.

The CLI isn't subject to the issue because it supplies a value for color_func.

items.title: using stopwords in CLI with python 2.7 throws casting error
items.body:
#### Description
Using the `--stopwords` flag with `wordcloud_cli` throws a casting error when running with Python 2.7 on Mac OS.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
* Run on Mac OS (where the default is Python 2.7)
* Create a non-empty plaintext file `echo "thee" > stopwords.txt`
* Run `wordcloud_cli --text input.txt --imagefile output.png --stopwords stopwords.txt`

#### Expected Results
No error is thrown.

#### Actual Results
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/wordcloud_cli", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/wordcloud/__main__.py", line 33, in main
    wordcloud_cli_main(*wordcloud_cli_parse_args(sys.argv[1:]))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/wordcloud/wordcloud_cli.py", line 178, in parse_args
    args['stopwords'] = set(map(str.strip, f.readlines()))
TypeError: descriptor 'strip' requires a 'str' object but received a 'unicode'
```

#### Versions
```
Darwin-17.7.0-x86_64-i386-64bit
('Python', '2.7.15 (default, Aug 22 2018, 16:36:18) \n[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 9.1.0 (clang-902.0.39.2)]')
('NumPy', '1.15.2')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "about.py", line 4, in <module>
    import matplotlib; print("matplotlib", matplotlib.__version__)
ImportError: No module named matplotlib
```

items.title: cli: Add support for installing and running"wordcloud_cli" on all platforms
items.body:
#### Description

After installing wordcloud as an editable install, it is not possible to run the `wordcloud_cli.py` script available in the source tree.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

After installing wordcloud locally using:

```
pip install -e .
```

and then trying to run the CLI with:

```
$ python ./wordcloud/wordcloud_cli.py --text examples/constitution.txt   --imagefile consitution.png
```

It fails with 

```pytb
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./wordcloud/wordcloud_cli.py", line 15, in <module>
    import wordcloud as wc
  File "/home/jcfr/Projects/word_cloud/wordcloud/wordcloud.py", line 25, in <module>
    from .query_integral_image import query_integral_image
SystemError: Parent module '' not loaded, cannot perform relative import
```

Note that running the installed cli works:

```
$ wordcloud_cli.py --text examples/constitution.txt   --imagefile consitution.png
```

But this is unlikely to work on windows and prevent developer from improving the CLI without having to reinstall it after each update, or having to  copy the script our and back into the right folder.

  * [x] [TravisCI: Add "secure" environment variables](https://github.com/scikit-build/scikit-ci/wiki/TravisCI:-Add-%22secure%22-environment-variables)
* [x] merge this PR
* [x] create and push a tag
  * [x] check that the wheels have been uploaded on [test pypi](https://test.pypi.org)
  * [x] try to install the wheel on windows, mac and linux using `pip install -i https://test.pypi.org/simple wordcloud`
  * [x] if everything looks good, do a commit removing `--repository-url https://test.pypi.org/legacy/ ` from `appveyor.yml`, `.circleci/config.yml` and `.travis.yml`

Once this is integrated, we could:
* [x] enable `flake8`
* [x] automatic deployment of the website on merge to master
* [x] fix code and enable generation of wheels for python 3.7.

another question is that, when the number of words is not too much, the space between each word is too big, not  close each other. when I change the parameter margin, it is not work.

Is there some methods to solve these questions?

looking forward to your reply!

items.title: Distributable .exe that imports WordCloud fails because of missing file
items.body:
#### Description
I compiled a python3.5 script that includes WordCloud using pyinstaller on Windows 10 in order to have a distributable exe file. The exe fails because it is looking for a file stopwords in folder Wordcloud in the user's temp directory. The script runs all fine when exectued in script or bash mode. The file is being looked up in a folder with cryptic name, which changes on every run. The foldername always starts with _MEI followed by some numbers.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
Compile python script on windows with pyinstaller and include line ``from wordcloud import WordCloud`

#### Error message

items.title: Wordcloud creating mask without words
items.body:
edit: the same problem also occurs with `wordcloud_cli.py --mask gist.png --image wc.py --text words.txt --no_collocations`

I've got this code, modified from an example.
```
from os import path
from PIL import Image
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import random
from wordcloud import WordCloud, STOPWORDS, ImageColorGenerator

d = path.dirname(__file__)

# Read the whole text.
text = open(path.join(d, 'words.txt')).read()

# read the mask / color image taken from
# http://jirkavinse.deviantart.com/art/quot-Real-Life-quot-Alice-282261010
alice_coloring = np.array(Image.open(path.join(d, "gist.png")))

wc = WordCloud(background_color="white", max_words=2000, mask=alice_coloring,
               max_font_size=40, random_state=42, height=1080, width=1080)
# generate word cloud
wc.generate(text)


def grey_color_func(word, font_size, position, orientation, random_state=None,
                    **kwargs):
    return "hsl(0, 0%%, %d%%)" % random.randint(60, 100)

# show
plt.imshow(wc.recolor(color_func=grey_color_func, random_state=3),
           interpolation="bilinear")
plt.axis("off")
plt.figure()
# recolor wordcloud and show
# we could also give color_func=image_colors directly in the constructor
plt.imshow(wc, interpolation="bilinear")
plt.axis("off")
plt.figure()
plt.imshow(alice_coloring, cmap=plt.cm.gray, interpolation="bilinear")
plt.axis("off")
plt.savefig("wc.png")

```
I'm on the latest pip3 version. What I'm trying to do is use the image below as a mask (with grey colors with `grey_color_func`), but the problem is all it's outputting is the mask. 
This is my mask:

![gist](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20865218/39723163-f1218942-5212-11e8-8a97-20e0d666ae57.png)

items.title: Needed a default unicode font included
items.body:
#### Description
<!-- Example: Duplicate words shown when input is sorted list -->
The font DroidSansMono.ttf included in the library does not support world languages. There are certain restricted environments where users can't  load their own files. Example is Databricks Community Cloud.

Code example is provided below, BTW, it is a good example for using WordCloud within Databricks Notebook for Spark.

Words are Punjabi in Gurmukhi Script, unicode set described here: 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gurmukhi_(Unicode_block)

items.title: Able to show letters?
items.body:
#### Description
<!-- Example: Duplicate words shown when input is sorted list -->
I would like to say thanks first for creating this package. It really makes my work easier. 
I am dealing with a document which includes lots of single-letter words, like "y" which represents "why". When I create my wordcloud they are disappeared. I would like to display them on the wordcloud. I didn't see any example wordclouds online showing single letters. I believe this package might not be designed to support this use case. I am just curious if there is something I can modify to show one-letter words. 

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
Here is the line of my code to set up the wordcloud: 

wc = WordCloud(collocations=False,
              background_color='white',
              font_path=font,
              mask=color_mask).generate(words)     
img_color = ImageColorGenerator(color_mask)
wc.recolor(color_func=img_color)


<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->
